close_symbols: object name storage / name buffers (e.g. object table or name arrays)
object name length constants (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or equivalent)
explanation:
For a sound MISRA C <string.h> bounds analysis you must inspect all code that OS_close calls (directly and immediately) and the data structures those callees manipulate: 

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: It validates and converts the file descriptor and fills/returns the token. Its implementation may perform string ops or copy names into token fields or global buffers — must verify any memcpy/strcpy use and indices.
- OS_GenericClose_Impl: Called to perform the actual close; may operate on object internals (paths, names, buffers) and could contain string.h usages that might access out-of-bounds memory.
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete: Finalizes deletion and calls event/cleanup routines; may copy/format strings when notifying or cleaning up resources.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit / OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel / OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish: Transaction helper routines used by ObjectIdGet/Finalize; they may manipulate temporary buffers or tokens and could use string functions — include to inspect any buffer operations related to the token lifecycle.
- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex / OS_ObjectIndexFromToken / OS_ObjectIdConvertToken: Token/index conversion helpers that access object tables or token fields; these are likely to index arrays or copy identifiers — necessary to ensure indices and copies are bounds-safe.
- OS_NotifyEvent: Notification routine called by FinalizeDelete; event formatting or copying could invoke string functions (e.g., building event text), so inspect its string usage and buffer sizes.
- OS_object_token_t: The token structure definition is required to know which pointer/array members are passed to string functions and their sizes/ownership (stack vs global), to determine if accesses could go out-of-bounds.
- osal_id_t / int32 / OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE / LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE / OS_SUCCESS: Typedefs and constants determine the control flow (which branches are taken) and thus which callees and code paths to analyze; you need them to follow conditional logic that may enable/disable string operations.
- object name storage / name buffers (e.g. object table or name arrays) and object name length constants (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME): Many object-management routines copy or format object names into global buffers or token fields; the actual buffer symbols and max-length constants are required to check whether any string.h calls use correct sizes and do not write past buffer bounds.

In short: include the three direct callees and each of their immediate helper routines that manipulate tokens/names, plus the token/type definitions and the global name buffers/length constants used by those routines — these are the places where string.h functions would appear and where bounds must be checked for MISRA compliance.
